post_text: California: our healthcare worker minimum wage is going up to $21 per hour starting June 1st. How does this affect small private practice physical therapy clinics? With constantly decreasing reimbursements and constantly increasing costs of doing business in healthcare, I am utterly discouraged as the small profits we get keep getting smaller. How have you or your company handled these challenges? We are mostly insurance based and the demographics in our area will not strongly support a pure cash based model. I want to keep our staff employed but our aides currently make around 17 per hour. Giving them 4-5 dollar raise overnight will definitely impact us, as we will have to pay higher payroll taxes on top of the actual raise. Aides apply for the job without much experience or training at all. Paying them $21 per hour as a new untrained healthcare worker seems unreasonable but that will be required starting June 1st. We tried to see if we can apply for a waiver but cannot find info on how to even apply. Any help, thoughts or suggestions would be appreciated.

comments.text: Simple . Don't hire unskilled help, there is EMR /AI and online assistants that can do that most work, and with the savings , pay the therapist /pta more and add the scheduling to there plate.

Tough Situation.  I was a PT Aide ions ago.  It is an entry level position.  Not a 44K per year job.  My First PT job was 18.26/hr + Bennies.  I guess there are two fundamental choices.  Increase volume/add ancillary sources of revenue or cut the Aide hours/week.

post_text: I've been seeing a lot about personalized POC vs Packages.  I've done packages in the past and honestly don't really like them.  Would someone explain what they're including in a Personal POC beyond 2x6 or something.  Thx

comments.text:
I always suggest a program versus packages ‚Äî and it‚Äôs not just semantics. 

Packages are a bunch of sessions bundled together.

A program has a start and finish, like an Eval +5 expanded treatment sessions. 

The client pays in full or possibly splits payments into two but the incentive for buying the program is not to save money

Instead it‚Äôs because that‚Äôs the way they will receive the best care and clinical outcome. Ôøº

I felt the same and looked back at what I had done with clients in a personalized POC before. I tend to see people 4-12 times so I made packages for 4, 8 and 12 sessions and recommend which package they get at eval. If they pay in full then they get a discount.

post_text:
Question about super bills and travel fee:

I have a cash pay client that has switched to an insurance where he‚Äôll likely be able to get out of network reimbursement. 
My super bills have always reflected my cash cash pay rate‚Ä¶ however, I normally charge him a travel fee. My assumption is that this won‚Äôt be reimbursed if I keep my same pricing and list a travel fee. 

Do I‚Ä¶ 

1. Increase my per unit pricing so the total is the same as I would regularly receive? As I write this it seems unethical to change? However, the per unit amount is significantly lower than what would be billed at an outpatient clinic and as clinics have different negotiated rates this seems acceptable? 
 
2. Keep pricing on my super bill the same and charge him the travel fee separately

3. Increase my pricing in general and offer those close by a discount. 

The only reason I bring up option 3 is if pricing changes draw any flags if another client has the same insurance and their super bill reflects cheaper per unit costs.

Most my clients are wellness based so I generally offer them or have as much experience with it. Thank you in advance!

post_text:
Hi everyone,
I'm a cash based PT. I was recently approached by someone who wants me to treat them after a MVA (I am in an "at -fault" state if that matters). Is there a way I would be able to treat them and have them be reimbursed by the auto insurance company, or should I refer them elsewhere?

comments.text: You can treat. I would bill the auto. Not sure your state but most pay pretty well. Unless it's moved to an attorney's hands, and they have Med Pay or PIP, you should be good. Just call the auto case manager or adjuster.

Just be aware, sometime the insurance will end up paying the settlement directly to the patient(even though we maintained contact with the adjuster throughout the process) which may include the physical therapy services. It happened to us, but luckily the patient was honest and paid us after she got her settlement check and we were reimbursed 100% of our billed rates.

post_text: Hey guys, I am looking at hiring a highly skilled therapist  - for PRN work , but they want 60 w2, and given their certifications, I agree with the rate buttttttt Medicare reimburses around 108 for 4 units - how do you determine what is too much wage wise ... I typically estimate  28% extra for taxes - thoughts ?? what do you all do when determining pay with standard medicare rates ... but specialized clinicians ....

comments.text: If their skills can bring in otherwise difficult to get business for other cheaper therapists then you can justify it.  Hard to do with PRN because they likely won‚Äôt be around consistently enough to build that business line.

You‚Äôre going to deduct taxes out of their pay though, so you‚Äôre really not paying them 60 an hour. Let‚Äôs leave it at 108 and 60 tho. You‚Äôre taking in 58 dollars a visit. Factor in cost of malpractice (shouldn‚Äôt be much, 10-15 a month to add on, EMR account, another 10 a month? Payroll?) you‚Äôre still making at least 25-30 dollars of passive income every visit no?

post_text:
Hello Everyone.  I have been seeing clients privately for 25 years. I have a good referral source in place and am ready to expand a bit. I have 3 therapists, who I know very well and are ready to take any referrals I can‚Äôt handle time-wise.  
My plan is to do the marketing, get the referrals, see the client for the initial evaluation/consultation, get payment for a Package of sessions, and then assign them to an appropriate therapist. 

My questions:

1.  What‚Äôs the best way to set up this relationship (I‚Äôm in California)?

2. I will have them sign the document declaring they are a separate business (I forgot the name of it). 

3. How should I pay them (Venmo, Zelle vs check etc)?

4. What % of the total fee that I collect should I pay them?
 
5. Do I 1099 my payments to them?

And there‚Äôs probably some considerations/ legal items I‚Äôm not thinking about as well. I‚Äôm open to suggestions!

Thank you!

comments.text: I would definitely pay by check & hopefully they will understand they would be independent contractors since they will be 1099‚Äôd at the end of the year. (I think I read that Venmo was going to start reporting when someone received more than $600/year from one source to the government & that might create a nightmare for the IC). The % of the total fee would depend on how much ‚Äúextra work‚Äù you‚Äôre needing to do ie billing, marketing, accounting etc. I pay my IC‚Äôs 80% of what I (my company) receives as payment. Make sure they carry their own liability insurance also. In some states, it was mandatory to have to carry workers comp insurance also.

post_text: Does anybody have any good, low cost book keeping app? I was recommended Wave, but it doesn't support HIPAA so they don't even let you sign up as a PT. Thank you!

comments.text:
My question for you is are you planning on invoicing through Wave? If not, wave would be fine (that‚Äôs what I use).  Wave can only see the money Square brings in for me and how much is in my bank account through the integrations.  By the time info gets to wave it‚Äôs completely separated from any patient identifying info by that point as it‚Äôs just numbers. 

For example, if Sally pays me $200 through Square, Wave only sees that $200 eventually was deposited into my account from square, not from Sally
I use Wave and just have my bank account sync so I don't have patient information in it. You just won't be able to do invoices

I get a small cut and the space isn‚Äôt sitting unused.
I work for a California based home health agency, and the per session rate for PT is $374. Just an FYI to compare your own rate to.

post_text:
I am a relatively new mobile business went full time is Feb. Have been doing Medicare and Cash.  I have someone who reached out that is 77yrs old and has been on work comp since 2008.  He said he was getting weakly PT for years until COVID through work comp.  My questions are‚Ä¶..does work comp pay well?  It it worth it to try to do this?  Is anyone willing to do a phone call with me to walk me through the process of who to take him on if it is?  
Thank you!

comments.text: I have 2 work comp pts - each different companies. One is really easy to get paid and the other one is crazy. I work with the nurse case manager and the adjuster (now work closely with the billing manager for the latter company üòú) and keep consistent lines of communication with authorization, clinical documentation, etc. I am otherwise fully cash practice (SLP + Executive Function Coach) They are more time consuming than other cases but have been good consistent income. The pay rates are not bad, I believe vary state to state - I am in MT. I just submit a 1500 form each month and an invoice. Also gave each company a W-9 in the beginning. Hope that helps!

There are different companies with different fee schedules.  In MD, IWIF is the big one and they pay very well.  In my state, it is also illegal to charge a wc patient cash for services or anything pertaining to the wc injury.

Hello all! 
I currently own an SCorp and have had some difficulties with two different CPAs since starting it in March 2022. Current CPA I used for 2023 - I am paying 1500$ for business tax prep and then 450$ for personal tax prep‚Ä¶ then I also pay 599$ a quarter for ‚Äúsmall business accounting‚Äù which includes quickbooks subscription and‚Ä¶ bookkeeping? I don‚Äôt even know lol. She set up Gusto for me to use where I pay myself through, I‚Äôve I fill out an accountable reimbursement worksheet every quarter and then everything else is run through quickbooks. I also have found every single call I‚Äôve had with her I do NOT understand the answer to the questions I‚Äôve asked such as what I should be paying myself. What Ive paid myself so far has been guesses. So questions: 

1. Is anyone else paying these kind of fees for tax prep and how much are you paying quarterly and for what exactly? 
2. If she cant answer my question of what i should pay myself, how do i know? I know it‚Äôs a ‚Äúreasonable salary‚Äù but obviously this will change based on business revenue.. 

Any insight would be appreciated

comments.text:
I have a mobile PT business but my husband and I own a hardware store, s corp.  The fees for accounting are what we pay our accountant but gross revenue dictates this. Quickbooks rates have substantially increased in last 15 years. I used to buy it for $299 and it was a working edition for 3 years. Now, it is 1 year subscription (with payroll) and $1400. 
Reasonable salary is what you could hire someone to do your job. Go on glassdoor and check out local salaries for your area. Your salary does not have to change based on revenue unless you are putting in more hours.

post_text: In your opinion what are the BENEFITS of cash or self pay PT? For the client not the therapist.

comments.text: Transparency - you know exactly what your visit costs - no waiting to see what insurance covers, waiting to see if you've met your deductible, or paying a co-pay and then getting hit with a balance bill months later.  You can make an educated, informed, and empowered decision about your health by knowing exactly what your care will cost.

Better quality care! Usually in cash-based people have longer appointments and undivided 1-on-1 care. Typically your goals really get listened to and there is time to work through problems and come up with a good, detailed HEP to help make improvements. It's an upfront investment, but usually saves money and time in the long run not having to do PT 2x/wk for months where you're only being seen for 10 minutes.

You can make an educated, informed, and empowered decision about your health by knowing exactly what your care will cost.

post_text:
Hello! I have a mobile therapy practice and have brought on ATP specialist to do wheelchair and seating assessments in the home. We are negotiating pay. She is contract and my intention was to pay per units billed, like my other staff, but she mentioned being paid for documentation since it takes significantly longer than a typical eval/treat. I have no problem with this, but I want it to be fair while also ensuring that the practice still makes some sort of profit. This is a new venture, so I'm wondering:
* Do other practices pay for doc time after wheelchair assessments, and if so, how much? (Not necessarily a number, but is it at 100% of their hourly treatment rate? I'm considering a percentage of her hourly rate since if it not revenue-generating time).
* If you pay for documentation time, do you cap it at, say, one hour, or do you have the clinician tell you how long it took?
* Speaking of, how long is a reasonable amount of time to spend documenting a standard wheelchair assessment? (We plan to use a version of the Houston Methodist Hospital fillable form).

Thank you in advance!!

-

comments.text:
I have done custom seating myself at part of my practice and I charge the patient more (cash pay) for these sessions because of the documentation and time to set up demos and coordinate with vendors. 
It does take time and effort to put all these pieces together. But also an experienced therapist who has their APT should not take long to do documentation. One hour tops even for a complex eval.  Straightforward evals take much less time, like 20-30 minutes.
IMO if you‚Äôre paying per unit, documentation of those units should be included in that pay. I.e agree on price per unit/visit/whatever and make it all inclusive and save the hassle.

Hello, clinicians! 
I want to know how much would you pay for a referral from a community nurse? 
Shall I pay for each visit or for each referral? 
I'm a cash based home Care PT.

comments.text: tell nurse you will take great care of the patients,  you'll be a resource for patients or for them,  you'll help patients find right providers from a trusted directory you have created,   ask patients to share their own feedback on your care/service with referral source when they go for follow up visits, this is the stuff that holds value in healthcare relationships and is legal and extremely valuable to you as a provider
Any kickback is illegal in Healthcare.

post_text:
I am curious if anyone has done this business model in the uncaged clinician group. Currently there is a 1 month wait for traditional OP PT in my area with many people complaining that the it is too long of a wait. I see people here and there on the side with my full time job with the government. With so many PTs out there wanting to be their own boss has anyone done a finders fee approach? For example if my company markets to medical providers that we can get their patients in for PT in one week, the PT I hire then sees all of them as they will colllect the total amount they bill through my company but then pay rent/finders fee for all the referrals I send to them? I already have a small space in my house or garage to charge rent if anyone is  treated or needs mobile PT. 

A big personal training gym I ran into does the same approach. They charge rent to all these personal trainers to use their facilities and they go out and hustle to get their own clients and build their business within this facility. Thanks for the advice.

comments.text: I get so many referrals that I‚Äôve been thinking about this

One time I covered for a therapist who was on an extended vacation and she had some clients that needed an emergency session. The therapist sent her client my info. After I did the session, like a week later when she got back in town, the therapist asked me to pay her the entire service fee and then said she would give me 30%. The problem was she did this after the woman paid me. I had no idea there would be a fee or what not. So I‚Äôm sure you can imagine this model isn‚Äôt so favorable for me. I actually refer people to my colleagues for free. Everyone comes back to me but I want them to get the help if they need it. 

What I have been doing instead: 
Emergency wellness services, where it‚Äôs a walk in basis and services are 3x the price. If urgent cares can do this, so can I. I started doing this because I had multiple clients say ‚Äúcan you just cancel someone? I‚Äôll pay 4x the price they were going to pay.‚Äù So now I designate a couple days a month for this. I‚Äôm still working out the logistics with my own practice. But I think this is the answer I‚Äôve been looking for so I don‚Äôt have to turn people in need away.

post_text: Anybody with a cash-based practice take a student before? I'm working on accepting a student for their clinical but wondering what kinds of liability forms I may need the student to sign. My practice is all private and cash-pay, no insurance at all. What things should I prepare or do before taking the student? Thanks in advance!

comments.text:
As a cash pay clinic there is really not much of a difference when accepting a student vs being insurance based - here are some things to be aware of to cover yourself and your business -

Make sure you have the proper liability coverage as a healthcare provider and as a business entity (OSHA, state regulations, whether you are set up as a mobile or brick n mortar or Telehealth - they are safe and not exposed to risk of themselves or your patients)

The PT school should be an accredited program and have all the necessary paperwork to help set you up as an affiliate educational site: usually they have liability coverage to cover their interns but still cover your bases on your end since they are treating your patients and working on your site or traveling with you in your vehicle) 

You have proper HIPAA, and intellectual property forms set up for them to sign. 

If you have a policies and procedures manual and since they will essentially be part of your team - make sure they read and sign off on that as well.

I would speak to the school CEC to give them a formal run down on how you run your practice and if it will fit all their requirements on number of hours worked, number hours of direct patient contact, setting up of objectives and expectations on your end as a CI.  Even interview the intern to be sure they will get what they might want to get out of their educational experience and if it meets your expectations and abilities.  

That about sums it up - reach out if you have a further inquiries.

Sorry I know this is not a direct answer to your question but I assume the student will be treating patients independently at your cash based practice. Do you think your cash paying patients will feel comfortable having a student treat them? I'm just asking because I assume they are coming to you and paying the cash pay services because of your experience and expertise.

full_thread_text:

My practice is all private and cash-pay, no insurance at all. What things should I prepare or do before taking the student? Thanks in advance!

COMMENT 1: As a cash pay clinic there is really not much of a difference when accepting a student vs being insurance based - here are some things to be aware of to cover yourself and your business -

Make sure you have the proper liability coverage as a healthcare provider and as a business entity (OSHA, state regulations, whether you are set up as a mobile or brick n mortar or Telehealth - they are safe and not exposed to risk of themselves or your patients)

The PT school should be an accredited program and have all the necessary paperwork to help set you up as an affiliate educational site: usually they have liability coverage to cover their interns but still cover your bases on your end since they are treating your patients and working on your site or traveling with you in your vehicle) 

You have proper HIPAA, and intellectual property forms set up for them to sign. 

If you have a policies and procedures manual and since they will essentially be part of your team - make sure they read and sign off on that as well.

I would speak to the school CEC to give them a formal run down on how you run your practice and if it will fit all their requirements on number of hours worked, number hours of direct patient contact, setting up of objectives and expectations on your end as a CI.  Even interview the intern to be sure they will get what they might want to get out of their educational experience and if it meets your expectations and abilities.  

That about sums it up - reach out if you have a further inquiries.

COMMENT 2: Sorry I know this is not a direct answer to your question but I assume the student will be treating patients independently at your cash based practice. Do you think your cash paying patients will feel comfortable having a student treat them? I'm just asking because I assume they are coming to you and paying the cash pay services because of your experience and expertise.

post_text:
Good Morning
I have a patient who is a family friend, I know they can‚Äôt afford their higher co-pay per visit‚Ä¶. I was wondering if I can give them a discount on their Co-pay? Or if I can completely forgive the entire co-pay? Business perspective I understand it may not be a good practice but looking for legal aspects‚Ä¶ please guide‚Ä¶

comments.text: No, you cannot. You have to collect their copay.  If their co-pay is too high then they should select an insurance that has a lower copay.  Maybe you can see them for wellness if it's not medically necessary

Technically if u r in network with their insurance. U r contracturally obligated to collect all co-pays, co-ins, deductibles etc.  In reality, u could just right it off.  But I would ask them not to mention to anyone that this was done.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: No, you cannot. You have to collect their copay.  If their co-pay is too high then they should select an insurance that has a lower copay.  Maybe you can see them for wellness if it's not medically necessary

COMMENT 2: Technically if u r in network with their insurance. U r contracturally obligated to collect all co-pays, co-ins, deductibles etc.  In reality, u could just right it off.  But I would ask them not to mention to anyone that this was done.

post_text:
Hi everyone, I am a cash pay PT owner and have been approached by an old patient who would like to work with me under lien. 

I have never worked with a lien before. First question, should I explore this? Second, any tips that I should know going in? 

Thank you!

comments.text: Cash pay means that you get paid at each session. Do you go to the supermarket and leave without paying? That‚Äôs how I approach it.

I‚Äôve treated many patients under an LOP with law offices. 
Positive: you will make more per visit for sure 
Negative: you will have to wait a long time to be paid. Could even be years, until the case settles.
The attorney will reach out to you and ask you to take a reduction. When I have done it, I‚Äôm billing twice Medicare allowable and then I will take a 20 or 25% reduction so it‚Äôs still ends up to be significantly more than Medicare. 
As long as not, all of your patients are in this situation, and you can wait for the cash flow, go for it in my opinion.ÔøºÔøº

post_text: I am so tired of trying to get patients to pay their statements. Our billing dept sends statements via email, then text, then mail. For those who have received at least 2 statements, I (owner) personally call and ask them to please pay. When they actually answer the phone, I'm often met with resistance and excuses. I don't want to write off the thousands of dollars owed, but I also want this off my plate. Any advice or strategies from other owners out there?

comments.text: Get every patients card on file. Have a list of those clients who have copays, deductibles, or coinsurance due. You run their card at the end of each day/week. Same for cash pay. Takes the burden off of the patient and puts it on the business, but guarantees payment. If they don't want a card on file, then tell them to find somewhere else to get treatment
If they are current clients, account needs to be paid up prior to their next treatment or that cannot be treated. Beyond that, collections agency

Takes the burden off of the patient and puts it on the business, but guarantees payment. If they don't want a card on file, then tell them to find somewhere else to get treatment

post_text: How much percentage raise did you get once you opened your own practice? Thanks in advance for sharing.

comments.text:
Very tough question to answer for several reasons. 

Initially my pay decreased because of the building phase. I now limit the number of visits I do per week for better work life balance so I can have tike to focus on my family, mentoring, teaching, other business endeavors, etc. For me money wasn't and isn't everything. 

Better to think about what you want to make and/or comfortable making and what it will take for you to get to that point. Consider things such as expenses and taxes that you'll have to pay when looking at what you will actually take home.
My phrase for a long time now: ‚Äòmy boss is super flexible, but the pay is terrible‚Äô lol

post_text:
Hey guys- quick question.
I am 100% cash pay using gsuite for everything. Do i need to register as an OOP with a variety of insurances for my patients to receive reimbursment with superbills? I have a superbill template i created but have not actually had a pt attempt to use it yet. As of now the majority of my sessions are fitness and sport performance. I was reading an earlier post on this page that got me thinking about this‚Ä¶.

comments.text:
In being 100% cash based, you will be viewed as an out of network provider with all insurance. This is the language that they would use to refer to you. 
With this in mind, your patients need to be the contact for the insurance. We have had legal advisors tell us that speaking with the insurance would be a possible issue with HIPAA. 
We give the superbill when requested then if there are issues, ask the clients to call while in the office and we walk them through.

Hi, this is a bit of a piggyback on the original question.  I'm also self pay and provide superbills to patients.  Does anyone provide instructions to patients in written form of the steps when contacting their insurance or use an app for potential reimbursement?

full_thread_text:

I am 100% cash pay using gsuite for everything. Do i need to register as an OOP with a variety of insurances for my patients to receive reimbursment with superbills? I have a superbill template i created but have not actually had a pt attempt to use it yet. As of now the majority of my sessions are fitness and sport performance. I was reading an earlier post on this page that got me thinking about this‚Ä¶.

COMMENT 1: In being 100% cash based, you will be viewed as an out of network provider with all insurance. This is the language that they would use to refer to you. 
With this in mind, your patients need to be the contact for the insurance. We have had legal advisors tell us that speaking with the insurance would be a possible issue with HIPAA. 
We give the superbill when requested then if there are issues, ask the clients to call while in the office and we walk them through.

COMMENT 2: Hi, this is a bit of a piggyback on the original question.  I'm also self pay and provide superbills to patients.  Does anyone provide instructions to patients in written form of the steps when contacting their insurance or use an app for potential reimbursement?

post_text: Any boxing bag recs?  And pros and cons hanging from ceiling versus floor? Thanks

comments.text: Do a wall mounted bracket (bag sold separately) in a corner if you want to save space. They make brackets that can swing and pull in/out from the wall. I bought one on Amazon for a reasonable price. Make sure you mount it to studs with 1x4 bracing between the sheet rock and metal punching bag bracket (spreads force out along the studs). The cost for the bracket and bag should be around $120-$150 total.

post_text: Question about cancelation fees -- I run a mobile practice. We charge $50 per cancelation. I've been having staff as if they get a "cut" of this fee. I've always been on the 'hard no' side of this debate because I feel like that scenario is rife for abuse. But now I don't know... Staff satisfaction is hugely important to me, and if it matters to them then I'd consider it. What do you all normally do and what's your experience? Thank you!

comments.text: Yes, we always paid staff for cancellations whether % of fee or hourly rate no matter if they were contract, 1099, or reg emp. That fee is to cover their time and expected pay just as much as yours.

If I was the one who wasted my time and gas driving to the patient‚Äôs house, but you got the cancellation fee, I would not feel appreciated. If I was the one who had to rearrange my schedule at the last minute because of the cancellation, but you got the cancellation fee, I would not feel appreciated. If I had to sit around and waste my time because I couldn‚Äôt find someone to fill the opening created by the cancellation, but you got the cancellation fee, I would not feel appreciated. If you feel that you have a trustworthy and conscientious staff that you want to keep, share the fee. If anyone abuses it, deal with them. But I feel that companies that appreciate therapists are rare, so when we are lucky enough to get hired by one we take care of that company and don‚Äôt abuse their appreciation. Is it worth $25-50 to you to make your employees feel like you value their time the way you would value your own?

Staff satisfaction is hugely important to me, and if it matters to them then I'd consider it. What do you all normally do and what's your experience? Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Yes, we always paid staff for cancellations whether % of fee or hourly rate no matter if they were contract, 1099, or reg emp. That fee is to cover their time and expected pay just as much as yours.

COMMENT 2: If I was the one who wasted my time and gas driving to the patient‚Äôs house, but you got the cancellation fee, I would not feel appreciated. If I had to sit around and waste my time because I couldn‚Äôt find someone to fill the opening created by the cancellation, but you got the cancellation fee, I would not feel appreciated. If you feel that you have a trustworthy and conscientious staff that you want to keep, share the fee. If anyone abuses it, deal with them. But I feel that companies that appreciate therapists are rare, so when we are lucky enough to get hired by one we take care of that company and don‚Äôt abuse their appreciation. Is it worth $25-50 to you to make your employees feel like you value their time the way you would value your own?

post_text:
Hi everyone, 
I'm an OT who is planning on doing cash pay only on the side. Couple questions.
-Am I good to call it wellness services and see patients without a referral? 
-Am I in violation of any laws by doing so?
-OT is not direct access but does that matter if I'm not providing OT but am instead providing wellness?

comments.text: What kind of services are you going to provide?

Do yourself a favor and review your practice act and ch 15 of Medicare benefits manual, so you have a clear understanding of the rules. You cannot have Medicare patients private pay for services that that would be considered skilled and medically necessary.  There are also the maintenance therapy rules which again, need to be skilled and medically necessary, but generally is not on a consistent basis unless you have a complex case and can justify the ongoing need for skilled care. Self pay for Medicare patients would be only for services not covered by Medicare.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi everyone, 
I'm an OT who is planning on doing cash pay only on the side. Couple questions.
-Am I good to call it wellness services and see patients without a referral? 
-Am I in violation of any laws by doing so?
-OT is not direct access but does that matter if I'm not providing OT but am instead providing wellness?

COMMENT 1: What kind of services are you going to provide?

COMMENT 2: Do yourself a favor and review your practice act and ch 15 of Medicare benefits manual, so you have a clear understanding of the rules. You cannot have Medicare patients private pay for services that that would be considered skilled and medically necessary.  There are also the maintenance therapy rules which again, need to be skilled and medically necessary, but generally is not on a consistent basis unless you have a complex case and can justify the ongoing need for skilled care. Self pay for Medicare patients would be only for services not covered by Medicare.

I have a former patient who wants to hire me for wellness to help him to work on overall strength. I‚Äôm driving to him and told him that my rate is $150/session.

He‚Äôs agreeable but doesn‚Äôt think he can afford to see me often. Am I pricing myself out or just setting my value?

comments.text: I was always taught that if you don't value your time, nobody else is going to do it for you üôè

If they want strength- they can find a trainer for $50/hour at the local gym. If they want a doctor of PT with unlimited expertise in healthcare as well as being the top specialist in strength and conditioning, who also travels as concierge, $150 is a steal. Do not change that price. Sometimes I‚Äôll consult with their trainer as a courtesy. So they‚Äôll see me for PT and they can get adjunct strengthening from the trainer. I do the same for massage therapists, chiropractors, etc. If they truly want your time and your expertise, they just have to pay for it. You can give them that option and I guarantee they‚Äôll choose you.

post_text: I currently have a cash-based mobile PT side hustle that I plan on doing full time soon. I was approached by a local PT who has a booming business (>6 month wait list) to work in her office (still be my own biz owner). She mentioned taking 20% of each visit for my patients and 50% of each visit when I see her patients. My patients are defined as anyone I bring in (for example, if I treat one of my mobile patients in the office) and her patients are anyone who calls to see her (so if someone calls to see her and learns of the 6 month wait list and doesn't want to wait, she'll direct them to me). 50% seems really high to me so I'm curious to get other's opinion's on this! For context, she has a great reputation, >20 years experience, has mentioned she'd be willing to teach me in some specialized areas and otherwise is very flexible with no min number of days/hours required and I would still work for myself. That being said, it's still 50% for a finders fee and I would be doing all of the work with the patient. Since I'm just going from side hustle to full time, I am a bit nervous about building up a case load and this would be one way that could majorly help with that. Does anyone else practice in a similar model? What % split seems fair and reasonable given this situation? I'd love to hear all thoughts an opinions! Thanks

comments.text: When you hire someone you plan to pay them 30-50% of the revenue they bring in. It sounds like she‚Äôs looking at it like you‚Äôre an employee

I can understand why this may sound as if the price is skewed to her benefit, but IT SHOULD BE! I won't advise on numbers or percentages but will offer you the view from the other side of the coin. When you are just starting out as your own business, it may seem as if the therapist is doing all the work(providing care to the pt and completing the documentation) and yes this is the revenue for the business. However, you need to realize how much goes into the greater picture of running a business than just treating patients and as many people in this group are just starting out, the full picture isn't visible yet(it wasn't for me until this year as I decide to grow my business with additional team members, services, products). As she is a business owner of a brick and mortar clinic, >20 years of experience, high reputation and an impressive 6 month waiting list, she has done EVERYTHING!  She has put in her time, effort, risk, sleepless nights, 60-80 hr work weeks, covering any shift a staff can't, learning HR/bookkeeping/accounting/compliance/risk mngmt/leadership and the cost/time each entails, mistakes in hiring/pricing/policies/EMRs/risk mngmt/scheduling, overcoming and improving on her processes to avoid those same mistakes in the future, cost of property, marketing and advertising,  paying staff instead of herself probably during slow times and so MUCH more!!!  She is also taking a risk on bringing any practitioner or employee into a business she has built for 20 yrs. Her profit margin is not 50% if she pays you 50%. If the business runs on a 5-10% profit margin and she pays a % higher to her team, that's a significant loss in the margin, so as the CEO, that comes out of her CEO salary so to speak. The COST of Attraction, Aquisition and Retention has been Tens of thousands each year for 20 years in addition to overhead costs of admin, environment, etc. We, as a profession, are kind, good-willed humans, and we can be that while being a business owner also, which includes setting your boundaries on what it is worth to the owner to continue running the business. Referring patients out would be giving away her very hard earned Attraction and Aquisition potential to only to give it to someone else for their profit. There is a great likelihood that referring them to someone like a new Uncaged clinician, she will not get them back because that Uncaged member is going to do everything in their power to retain that client, right?  So then she would have worked for years on Attraction and Aquistion(the most costly for the owner) only to give the source of revenue to someone else. That first phone call can make or break a client, so that's the most important call, that's when you get the commitment from the client. For the same reason becoming Uncaged is risky, is the very reason she must work her numbers wisely. Imagine working diligently to get your schedule up to your first 10 clients, your max,  and having to give them to someone else for no return on investment to you. She has INVESTED 20 years of building trust and respect of the community!  Huge accomplishment! Congratulations to her!  Now you just have to decide if you want to be part of what she has already built or if you are ready/willing/capable of doing the same.   Either way, choose what is right for you. Respect the process. Even if you were to work with her and didn't appreciate the numbers, you may be able to learn lots just being involved in her system with your new frame of mind as a new business owner. The whole point, there's another side to the coin. Thanks for letting me share. Good luck no matter what you decide!

post_text: Question on health plans when starting your own practice. Any good resources or stories on plans that worked for families? This is a concern going on my own as I currently receive as part of my benefit package.

comments.text: There really isn‚Äôt. This is why I could never go out on my own. Expect at least $2,000/month coverage for a family. You can find less, but your deductible will be outrageous or nothing will be covered. Contact a health insurance broker.

One option is to check your state‚Äôs health insurance marketplace (the Affordable Care Act aka Obamacare). See if there are insurance brokers associated with it who can help you look at plans on the marketplace (the brokers are no cost to you) and ask them if you might qualify for tax credits which lessen your monthly cost. I did this after a layoff and was pleasantly surprised about the affordability - though I‚Äôm not getting family coverage so can‚Äôt speak to that part.

post_text: What‚Äôs the going rate for cash based pelvic PT in Los Angeles? Someone I know is being charged $250 per visit. Is that reasonable?

comments.text:
The only person who can deem it reasonable or not is the patient/client. Does he/she feel that what they are receiving is worth the rate they're paying? Because we all value things differently, and see that value from different points of view.

My rates are well above the rates of anyone else in my area. But every one of my clients are convinced that what they receive is well worth every penny they spent. Does the fact that my rates are higher than anyone else around me mean that my rates are unreasonable? People who choose not to work with me probably think so. People who do choose to work with me often feel I am undervaluing my services. The eye of the beholder is a powerful thing.

That‚Äôs within average rates for pelvic PTs in this area. But I also think this post has an undertone of judgment about someone else‚Äôs rates. As Joe said above, the only person who can deem it reasonable is the patient/client. If they feel the service is valuable at that rate, they will pay it. If they don‚Äôt, they won‚Äôt. There‚Äôs room in the market for different levels of service priced at different rates.

Hello,

I have an opportunity to work in a gym but they suggested they would like me to bill through them which I said no to. I have a meeting with them next week and want to negotiate pricing/terms. Any suggestions or recommendations would be appreciated. Thank you!

comments.text:
Tell them you can‚Äôt do a percentage or fee per client with them because of anti-kickback laws that could make it seem like they are referring people to you just to increase their profit rather than for the benefit of the client. 

Then pitch a sliding scale or flat rate rent that increases over time as you get established, with a cap.
I would suggest pushing to just pay a rental fee, otherwise that it would make it very complicated for your business moving forward if you ever went separate ways

Virtual session / legal question:

I was just reffered a client who travels frequently and wanting to do virtual sessions. I have questions about he legality of treating virtually in a different state than I am licensed. 

Keep in mind I am cash pay. And will be "providing" the service from my licensed state.
Do i just bill as a wellness visit to get around this?

Any guidance?

comments.text: IFFFF you can justify that the session is Wellness, then yes.  But that needs to be made clear with the client - that the virtual sessions are wellness sessions

It doesnt matter that you are cash pay or not.  If you are providing skilled services, it falls under your state's practice act re: virtual visits.  If it is wellness than you should be fine.  If it is skilled and u just call it wellness than that is a problem.

post_text:
Hello everyone,

I have a few questions where I am stuck currently. Sorry for the long post. 

I started my business as a side hustle and planning to go all in next year. I started with my price being below average according to other practitioners. I am cash based/out of network concierge PT. 

1. I want to increase my pricing starting January, with travel time, one on one hour, I do not think it is sustainable long term with the current pricing I have. Does any one have a letter format or any templates they use to send it to the clients? 
If I have new clients, do I tell them the new price from January, how to go forward with this? 

2. I have started offering pelvic floor PT services and added that as a specialty. I have different pricing for pelvic floor patients as compared to non pelvic floor clients. I am not very sure if I should keep the pricing different or same for pelvic floor clients, if it‚Äôs higher, should I increase the time that I treat the pelvic floor patients for? 

Do any of you have different pricing for things you treat or do you keep it all the same. Any guidance or help here would be greatly appreciated. 

Thank you !

comments.text:
I charge the same rate for everything that I do from physical therapy to a wellness visit. This was good advice given to me a while back. The reasoning is that if you start seeing someone for wellness and charging them one rate and then they tweak their knee and they need you to take care of that, then it‚Äôs difficult to adjust the rate. So i suggest you just stick to one rate for your time‚Ä¶Period. 
As for your current clients, you could grandfather them in at their current rate, or slightly increased rate, if you‚Äôd like. However, if they take a hiatus from you for any reason, then I would suggest that they return at the current rate.

You also have the option of grandfathering in current clients. If it's only a side hustle and you don't have a full caseload but want to honor and keep current loyal clients, you can raise your price point for new patients but keep your price point for current patients. Some of our clinicians have done this. I did it for a couple long standing patients that I had been seeing for a long time.

post_text:
I approached a community center to use a portion of their pool to see patients for aquatic therapy. They are asking for 30% of revenue.
1) is this legal in healthcare, to pay a portion of revenue, especially if any of their members were to come to me for treatment?
2) is it just me or is 30% ridiculously high?

comments.text: 30% is fairly standard. 20-40% is normal range, but can go to 50/50 even depending on what's included etc.

It can depend on your state. In some places it's not legal for them to charge you more than what would be considered a reasonable lease rate, in those states a percentage could get the facility in trouble. Some places charge providers a flat fee per hour with a monthly capped charge.

COMMENT 1: 30% is fairly standard. 20-40% is normal range, but can go to 50/50 even depending on what's included etc.

COMMENT 2: It can depend on your state. In some places it's not legal for them to charge you more than what would be considered a reasonable lease rate, in those states a percentage could get the facility in trouble. Some places charge providers a flat fee per hour with a monthly capped charge.

post_text:
**Hi!  How do you handle treating a patient who was involved in an auto accident (other person's fault) if you are cash pay?  **

**Do you have them pay up front and then the patient gets reimbursed or do you wait until it is settled and then you get paid?**

** If I make up a document for them to sign (other than basic intake form) what details should I include???**

**Any advice greatly appreciated!!! :)**

comments.text:
If there is an open lien/case you have some options. The safest is just charge your cash rates up front and stick to your business as usual.

Another example/option, I have a standing contract with a PI group here that refers us cases, we see their patients and bill them on a net-30 at Medicare rates. Then when the case settles we get an additional agreed upon percentage. Has been lucrative so far and prevents us from being on the hook for the 8-14 months it takes for the case to settle but we still get a portion of the upside.

post_text: Need some thoughts on an opportunity. I currently treat both MCR and cash pts with my fully mobile practice . I charge $150/visit. I was approached by a local country club with a large membership. They would like me to treat their members at the club. They would take 20% of monies. I told them $175/ visit (the idea is to recoup the 20%).  I would be there for maybe 4-5 hrs at a clip. Am I being greedy to ask for the $175/visit? Thoughts on $175 for eval and then $150 return visits? Thanks, everyone!!!

comments.text: Someone in a pelvic floor group I follow put it this way: ‚ÄúI just paid $200 to have a clown at my kids bday party for an hour‚Äù. Consider that when setting your rates.

I‚Äôve actually have done this in the past. Worked well but the must earn their 20% , I believe it was 20% for me as well 

1. You cannot treat Medicare there unless you get that site blessed by Medicare 
2. The country club better have all the equipment you need to effectively do your job 
3. The country club likely will be handling all the money up front ie drawing from their members accounts on a monthly basis   So you need to ensure your books are accurate so they pay you correctly 
4. The country club should assist you on scheduling their members with their front desk/spa staff. 
5. They should also market on your behalf as 20% of 10 clients vs 100 clients is much more advantageous to them. 
6 your rates seem low but all of that is area dependent, and what you are comfortable charging. We aee 275 eval 175 follow up 350 ultrasound diagnostics. Commonly an eval will pull in $625 in an hour  and the members love it.

post_text:
13‚Ä¶ I have 13 patients scheduled.

It has taken 3 solid years of highs and lows, second guessing myself on this journey, and wondering if I made the right move.  But 3 years and I hit my target goal of 12/week‚Ä¶ 12 was my magic number to average 10/week.  12 would let me do what I set out to do from the beginning‚Ä¶ ‚Äúpart time hours, full time pay‚Äù‚Ä¶ 12 meant not needing to rely on prn gigs to get by‚Ä¶ 12 meant I made the right choice to step away from a job where I was throwing myself into working for a company heart and soul and being told it was never good enough- see more patients, more productivity, never going to make more than the bottom 25% of the advertised company pay bracket for my position despite doing all the extras and being there for 10 years‚Ä¶ 

So today I celebrate 13!  I know it is just 1 week and I hope it is the first of many‚Ä¶ I know I will still have highs and lows in this business ownership life‚Ä¶ but I encourage you to keep trucking along because there is a better way to provide healthcare, a beautiful collaborative way to connect with other therapists and promote this direction of patient care‚Ä¶ we‚Äôve got this!!!

comments.text: Congratulations üëèüëèüëè
I am loving this!!! üíï

post_text: Hi all! I was recently asked if I could stretch a former patient after he leaves inpatient rehab outside of my work affiliation. Does anyone know a standard going rate for that? And would you recommend getting individual insurance or creating a signed document for legal purposes?

comments.text: Yes,creating a signed consent, and getting individual malpractice insurance. I use CM&F, it is better priced than HPSO.  As for the going rate, hopefully someone will chime in, as there are a few clinicians on here who do that.   Check the files above, I think there are some sample consents, but always best to run it by an attorney to be safe. Good luck!!!

for rate I would try to look up what personal trainers in the area normally charge and go on the 75% range since it won‚Äôt be true ‚Äúskilled therapy‚Äù but you want it to be worth your time as well.

full_thread_text:

Hi, everyone, newbee here, still leaning so pardon the question if it seems obvious.

I just saw an answer on another question that its a federal law that we can not see a Medicare patient self pay, even if we dont take Medicare so I wanted to ask....

I have a DON at a ALF who asked if I'd see a patient self pay who is on hospice services, the patient and family still want PT, is it illegal for me to see him self pay? He has a Medicare supplement policy...the family and DON said he has used all of his benefits for PT...

I read up on it and it seems that I'd have to register with Medicare as a non-participating provider and still bill Medicare to see if he can get reimbursed? Is that correct?

comments.text: can see for unskilled OOP.  For skilled care u can not charge cash.

post_text: I just spent 30 minutes on the phone with a lawyer who I suspect might as me to travel for a deposition. She asked me to send my fee, which I really want to get right in case I'm billing for a lot more hours. My gut said to just bill what I do for patients because my time is my time, but I scrolled through some old threads and see that people are charging a LOT more. What's the justification/ how do I know what to charge here?

comments.text:
I met a PT randomly who was asked to be an expert witness of sorts. He didn‚Äôt want to do it so quoted the attorney 1200/hr with 4 hr minimum.

They paid him upfront.

I‚Äôve charged $400/hr, based on what I found as ‚Äúthe norm‚Äù. 
Also, be specific in you fee schedule to include that you get paid for time scheduled, even if they have to reschedule it. 

(I was subpoenaed to give a deposition on a case as a witness/expert, and had to take a day off from work, to do it, and they cancelled it 1 hour before I was scheduled to be there)

What's the justification/ how do I know what to charge here?

COMMENT 1: I met a PT randomly who was asked to be an expert witness of sorts. He didn‚Äôt want to do it so quoted the attorney 1200/hr with 4 hr minimum.

They paid him upfront.

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôve charged $400/hr, based on what I found as ‚Äúthe norm‚Äù. 
Also, be specific in you fee schedule to include that you get paid for time scheduled, even if they have to reschedule it. 

(I was subpoenaed to give a deposition on a case as a witness/expert, and had to take a day off from work, to do it, and they cancelled it 1 hour before I was scheduled to be there)

post_text:
Hello!

I am doing physical therapy in California which means I have an scorp set up. Anybody doing contracts with home health companies full time? Or even just with one company?
My situation is that I potentially have a company to contract with at an hourly rate. I Would work a regular 40 hr home health schedule. Does anyone do this? Would I need to have any special compliance requirements on my end (something related to the modules that I do for with my current travel recruiting company, etc)?

Any feed back would be helpful!
Thanks!

comments.text:
What you‚Äôre doing seems super common and straight forward in Ca

1) work with CPA to get S-Corp
2) get your own insurance
3) give the HH Agency your company tax ID number
4) open a bank account under your business 
5) they pay you. Your CPA handles the rest

6) I recommend taking 35% of every check and putting it in a separate savings account to get ready to pay Uncle Sam come next tax season

So I'm based out of nj- and I did work as a contractor part-time, but hours and days were set. I also interviewed with a home health company and asked if they would pay for an s Corp and both companies act turned it down bc in NJ we have abc laws that makes it in my opinion harder for an employer to pay the s Corp or even an LLC. I'm not sure if Cali has anything similar but I learned the hard way that many didn't want to pay me as a business entity but had no issues paying me as directly. I know this doesn't answer your question, but maybe if you Google abc laws you may or may not find some for Cali that may help you

If athletes have major things going on that I can‚Äôt ‚Äúquick fix‚Äù then I see them through my cash based company! COMMENT 1: I use US Bank. Found all the other big banks had too many fees. Credit unions can be a good choice as well. Patients pay me through cash, check, debit/credit card through Square, venmo mostly.

COMMENT 2: Credit cards. I would never want to carry cash. Plan your rate with credit card fees in mind.  I personally don‚Äôt like it when businesses charge a credit card fee. So I just ‚Äúinclude‚Äù the fee in my rates.

post_text:
Hello üôÇ 

I put together a checklist of things that I would consider paramount to include in any rehab, wellness or recovery plan 

1. Are you hitting the physical activity guidelines (2+ days per week of muscle strengthening activity and 75-150per week of vigorous aerobic activity)
2. Are you sleeping 7-9 hours a night?
3. Are you hitting your recommended protein target (1.6g/kg body weight)? 
4. Are you hitting your daily fiber goal (25-30g)
5. Are you getting >5 servings fruit and veg per day?

I see a lot of talks in here about what to charge for dry needling only sessions, how much a red light therapy coffin costs or what frequency vibrations should be in the vibration stimulation room. Are these the most health promoting things we can be spending time and money on? 

If your patients don‚Äôt hit these markers, is there a push by you to achieve them? If not, why? 

Finally, are you hitting these markers yourself?

post_text:
Superbill question.  

I'm a PT working in home with infants, fully OON.  I charge a flat rate regardless of session length.  I use Jane and don't have many families wanting superbills, but when I do I had initially been inputting codes without itemized costs and it generally worked.  Now I have my second case asking for itemized cost by code.  My visits are most often around an hour so I just divided my flat rate that way and it worked for the previous baby that always worked out to 4 units, but this baby's visits have fluctuated more, so I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do.  If I say it's 31.25 per unit that works for most sessions but there have been some with only 2 or 3 units but I still charged 125... so there is a gap.  

Doesn't seem correct to keep changing the itemized code cost.

I keep seeing people say to use prompt pay discount to arrive at their flat rate fee, but that would require me to falsely jack up my itemized cost and always then discount it (by varied amounts)?  
... But that also doesn't seem right

Sorry for the overexplain, hopefully it made sense.  Thanks for reading! üòÖ

comments.text: I‚Äôve been there too‚Ä¶ I unfortunately just charged a lesser rate (2-3 units instead of 4) for those sessions. It doesn‚Äôt happen often.

I would make your itemized cost equal per unit and equal the lesser unit amount and then apply discounts if the unit amounts were higher than anticipated.  E.g. $125 cash typically gets 30 minutes or 2 units, but I went for 38 minutes this visit and per 8 minute rule I could charge 3 units, but I gave a discount for the third unit, so no charge for patient Ed, but charge for neuroreed 1 unit at 62.50 and therex at 1 unit 62.50 rates. Pretty sure you can have void units on activities you don't want to bill a full unit on Jane e.g. 7 minute activity is 0 units, but still doc the activities and cite it as no charge üòâ just follow 8 minute rule, match number if units to total time (60 minute session is typically 4 units),  err on side if caution. People are usual pleased with discounts or write off, but frown in session to session breakdown discrepancies like there 1 unit was this amount and now it is more expensive... hope this helps

post_text: We grew by default and not design = restructuring. Has anyone gone through the process of transitioning 1099s to W2s, and how did you figure out their rate change, etc? Do you pay per visit, hour, unit billed? Do you offer a non-clinical rate to promote business development and community connection? I know where I want to go, grow and scale, just don‚Äôt know how to do it.

comments.text: Good problem to have!

My husband is a labor and employment attorney and can speak with you if you want. This is very state dependent as pay is all about your local market as well as what is required to be paid or not paid tax and benefits wise. Also need to decide if your employees are hourly or salary‚Äîthis would dictate meal and rest breaks as well as overtime.

post_text:
Anyone who works with runners, have you found sponsoring local races to be a good ROI? 

All race directors I‚Äôve reached out to charge $500+ to sponsor a race and set up a booth near the finish line. 

As a new business with limited capitol, I want to make sure I spend my marketing dollars wisely. 

Thanks!

comments.text: Offer free post race massages. They would probably wave the sponsor fee. ROI is hit or miss. Good for name recognition but we haven‚Äôt gotten a lot of direct referrals. Do about 4 races per year all through the same company.

We offer to bring our recovery boots in exchange for the sponsorship, which most of the time the race director will do because it‚Äôs a nice service. I hate stretching people after runs so I like this WAY better - I get to talk to the runners for 10-20 minutes while they are in the boots and 90% of the time, we get to talking about their pain or injuries which leads to me being able to make suggestions (which leads to them asking for my card).  I have everyone sign in on the iPad while they are in the boots so I can collect their email addresses too.

post_text:
Cash based Colorado mobile PT here. I know this has probably been asked‚Ä¶I have a client who wants mobility/personal training for he and his wife in their home. Do you have different liability/consent forms for personal training services? Do you change your fees? Do I need to create a dba for just wellness? 

Thank you for the advice!!

comments.text:
You don't need to change your fees if you don't want to. You're still using plenty of your PT-trained brain for personal training. 

You don't need a separate DBA unless you want one. Frankly I think that having two different names for your PT vs. wellness services is both unnecessary and confusing.

Joe Camoratto probably has more information to answer your waiver question.

Also in CO. I have two business for it but that‚Äôs because I want my wellness services to expand outside of CO. Up to you how you want it though! I charge my same fee (minus the eval fee for wellness). My consent forms are more general for wellness and I had an attorney draft them

post_text: When applying for a new job, can the new employer see or have access to previous salary. I‚Äôm leaving my current employer to go to a clinic where in my interview they mentioned I would qualify for up to $15 per hour more. Ôøº

comments.text:
They can call your old employer and ask for salary, but they may not do that, and your old employer may not give them the information even if they ask.  That would be the only way for them to get that info.  There are a lot of "what if's" in that scenario.

But my question is-- why do you care if they know?  It's irrelavent what you made before.  If the new employer is offering to pay more, and/or your old employer was underpaying you, that's obviously why you want to leave (and a very good reason to leave at that).  The only numbers that are important here are the standard/average pay for a therapist with your education and experience in your area, and the cost of living in your area.  Demand what you're worth, and don't let them dictate that to you!
tell them you were making $150/hr

But my question is-- why do you care if they know?  It's irrelavent what you made before.  If the new employer is offering to pay more, and/or your old employer was underpaying you, that's obviously why you want to leave (and a very good reason to leave at that).  The only numbers that are important here are the standard/average pay for a therapist with your education and experience in your area, and the cost of living in your area.  Demand what you're worth, and don't let them dictate that to you!

post_text: Hello! Are any of you out there mobile therapists working with older adults with UI.  It looks like there is some research on transtibial and presacral TENS being beneficial for urge UI.  Are any of you doing that?  If so, are you getting results?  And what machine do you have?  Thanks!

comments.text: Laura McKaig Any insights?

Yep!

I like the really cheap ones and just make sure I can adjust the pulse rate so that I can set it between 10-20hz. Gotta read the fine print. Something like:
"Pulse Rate: Adjustable, from 2-150 Hz, 1 Hz/step"

If they can use it independently, I have them purchase one. If I want to supervise them, I bring a machine each visit.

Obviously, I follow all estim precautions and contraindications. :)

post_text:
Hi all!  I'm just getting started, and wondering about how to set my pricing.  

I am planning to offer a hybrid-type model (for now, I have a nice treatment area set up at my house - maybe it could be a little strange for some patients, but I figure some people may not want me coming to their home!?).  

When you offer pricing, do you charge extra for traveling to your patient vs treating at your brick and mortar location?  I'm not sure exactly how to go about this.

comments.text: I treat from my own home studio. At first I thought it might be a turn off,  but I have everything one would need. If cash paying and patients wanting me to come to them, I‚Äôd charge more and wouldn‚Äôt travel more than 20 minutes. So far, (in the 1.5 years I‚Äôve been doing this) everyone is local and comes to me.

I charge a flat rate for my visits. I actually make more on a mobile visit because there's no overhead. If I see someone at the sublet I have to pay the gym. Also depends on the state I think in some it's illegal or frowned upon to do a travel charge. Jarod Carter had a few examples of ways to manage that on his podcast.

post_text: I currently do PT contract work  through my mobile PT LLC for a home health agency to round out my schedule, maintain predictable income, and through whom I often get a lot of referrals  when people are not home health appropriate etc. the company recently sold and is going from hourly contracted rate to per visit contracted rate. I will obviously need to re negotiate my contract but would like to have an idea of a pay range for per visit home health rate so that I can negotiate proactively. Anyone have experience with this? Thank you

comments.text:
I‚Äôm in North Texas‚Ä¶ rates directly to agency for me are $100 for eval/reeval/dc and $80 for routine. I don‚Äôt do SOC for the one agency I work with directly but I do them for 2 contract groups. Ranges from $110-140 depending on which group and where the patient is.

Nice to have flexibility to simply say no when I want. If they are desperate for help, they have no choice but to pay. I wouldn‚Äôt take less than $140 for SOCs in your situation. I know of one PT getting $180 for an SOC in rural Mississippi. You have to account for your non billed time driving which is going to be higher in rural automatically.

I do the same and am paid per visit. Where do you live? I‚Äôm in Texas, and it will greatly vary from state to state (I.e. California rates are way higher), but I get paid 80-90 a visit on average for all visits. I do not do SOC visits. Just eval, RE, treat, DC! Been considering asking for a slight pay bump here recently to 90+ per visit. I‚Äôll see if that goes over well lol! Greatly helps me do all of the above you mention being a PRN home health PT.

post_text:
Does anyone know how you can show your proof of income as self-employed? Like not what the business makes...what I actually pay myself. I use quickbooks self employed and use the profit first model and do owner's draws twice a month. 

I can see what I've withdrawn, but I'm wondering how I can generate a document for proof of income. Any ideas?

comments.text: I've used Canva to create a "paystub." I use Profit First and I had to show proof of income for something. They wouldn't take my taxes or PL sheet. The "paystub" showed my owner's draw in a more standard format.

You could make your business an LLC and pay yourself like an employee. Its a hassle, but probably the only thing that will be sufficient for proving income to buy a house. 

Talk to a mortgage broker & hire a CPA to help you for a few years to get the right kind of documentation. 

Otherwise...tax returns & back statements are your only option. 

Good luck!

Something I‚Äôve done is create pdfs of specific info (postpartum return to exercise, csection scar care, etc) and place a flyer with QR codes in doctor offices, gyms, coffee shops, etc. The QR code takes them to a landing page (I use mailchimp also) they can enter their name and email and then the requested material is automatically emailed to them. post_text:
Hey gang, I'm hoping to get some feedback from the group about a scenario I stumbled into. I have been doing home health and concierge so I don't have any experience in outpatient billing. 

Recently had a meeting with a chiropractor that a patient referred me to. The chiropractor is interested in me coming into his office to treat his patients. He will not charge me to use his facility.  My rate is $200 per session for my concierge patients. The chiropractor said that his office could bill and pay me my rate. He said he hadn't done enough research to determine the exact specifics yet. Is it possible to be reimbursed by insurance for $200 for 4 units? His office does SOAP notes. 

What do you think about this? What other sorts of questions should I be asking?
Thanks for your feedback.

comments.text:
He is NOT likely to get your rate in reimbursements..so get paid as you go not when he gets reimbursed 
And
Oversee the billing maybe by signing it
And
Do your own notes
Nope, he won‚Äôt even come close with 4 units but who is doing the documentation??  Shady clinics have been known to change the billing to way more than what a therapist originally put in.

I‚Äôm interested in hearing from folks who have used Gusto for payroll and how that compares pros/cons to square payroll, ADP, quick books, paychex etc. 

I have a small practice and would like a system that handles 2-8 employees efficiently

comments.text:
One con is if you want to set up a pay per visit type of model, there currently Isn‚Äôt an option for this.

Square I liked but they didn't do next day payroll processing and it was a must for where I was at in my business at the time. Using Gusto now and I have been very pleased so far. Smooth onboaring, lots of tools for the same price as ADP basic.

post_text: Does anyone have a financial agreement for clients to sign? And would you mind sharing? I‚Äôm a cash pay practice and looking for verbiage in how to state that they agree to have a card on file and that card will be charged 50% of the treatment fee if there is a late cancellation.

comments.text: I see what‚Äôs posted but I would also suggest you have a separate cancellation policy agreement & charge agreement form that is signable & printable if needed. It should really cover you to say that the card on file is accepted to be charged for any vists that are cancelled inside of X hours/days &/or for no shows. It also helps to have the wording of what your business charges show up as on their credit card statement. You might want to add language to cover yourself in that the person will be responsible for any & all fees related to any chargebacks or disputes. There‚Äôs growing issues with people disputing things that are not actually charged anymore but it can take time for the bank (not the credit card processor) to catch up to the dispute file & can be a mess for a business owner if the client is being dishonest. You also might need a card on file agreement (which the card is actually filed with the payment processor & not you directly) if you‚Äôre doing that to be able to run these types of charges.
I‚Äôll post one here

post_text: I currently have a pt that is being seen though insurance. There is a $30 copay per visit that my company has to charge.  The family is not able to afford the co-pay and is needing to step down therapy.  Is there a legal way for my company to continue treatment without billing for the copay?

comments.text: Billing doesn‚Äôt mean collecting

Company can offer a payment plan to pay off the balance. But what bother me in this situations, that asking not to pay a co-pay or deductable really means asking the company owners to pay for their therapy. The same people who ask to not pay co-pays and  stating that it is too much for them , go and have nails done every two weeks or eat out weekly (or more often), etc. When a plumber comes and fixes something in 10 min and charges much more than $30  people pay and do not say anything. But for some reason when it comes to therapy, people do not want to pay. People pay enormous amount of money to veterinarians and usually it is all cash. It is all about the perceived value....Therapists are already underpaid professionals. And if we do not value our services, no one will. The reimbursement for our services is going down. A lot of times these $30 is the make or break for the company . Or it is what allows a company to pay our salaries. Please note, I am not an owner of any company.

COMMENT 1: Billing doesn‚Äôt mean collecting

COMMENT 2: Company can offer a payment plan to pay off the balance. But what bother me in this situations, that asking not to pay a co-pay or deductable really means asking the company owners to pay for their therapy. The same people who ask to not pay co-pays and  stating that it is too much for them , go and have nails done every two weeks or eat out weekly (or more often), etc. When a plumber comes and fixes something in 10 min and charges much more than $30  people pay and do not say anything. It is all about the perceived value....Therapists are already underpaid professionals. And if we do not value our services, no one will. The reimbursement for our services is going down. A lot of times these $30 is the make or break for the company . Or it is what allows a company to pay our salaries. Please note, I am not an owner of any company.

post_text:
Next week I start one day a week working on my own practice! I have a space, an LLC, a name, a treatment table, and a disdain for insurance billing. I have never done it on my own, but know I don't really want to. 
- I will likely have to contract with Medicare because my ideal population is Geriatric. Otherwise, I live in a pretty rural area with significant low-income population. 
- What I am wondering, or hoping I guess, is that some others who are practicing cash based in rural, low- income areas may be able to offer advice or ease of my concerns about charging enough to make this all worth it and not scaring away patients d/t cost.

comments.text: Out of curiosity, what does it mean to be ‚Äúin contract‚Äù with Medicare? Doesn‚Äôt that defeat the purpose of being cash-based? Sorry, i‚Äôm a new grad so this is all new to me.

I am working one day/week in a small rural town. I am finding it very difficult to drum up the business I would like. I think I can break into some community education and make a couple bucks that way, and possibly pick up some clients too; but cash pay is extremely new to people here and they believe in their insurance. Tough to break through that facade and clue them in to the benefits both physically and financially of cash-pay healthcare.

post_text:
I‚Äôm in the very very early stages of starting my own practice. A friend (think a little more than acquaintance) asked me to see her kiddo. We‚Äôve had a couple of phone calls with mom debating if the kiddo needed to be seen. A few weeks later and I‚Äôm scheduled to see them Thursday. Mom mentioned that she wants to pay me to do this informal assessment. 

So here is the question: do I charge full price or provide a friend discount, especially considering I am JUST leaving my current job and going out on my own. No standardized tests etc. 

Thank you for any insight!

comments.text: I‚Äôd provide discount and ask if she‚Äôs pleased, if she would do a Google review, refer friends, etc.

You value yourself by the price you charge. Also, when people PAY, they PAY ATTENTION. During the height of C-vd I was giving away advice to friends who were pregnant and realized I resented them bc they weren't following through on my advice... but they had no investment so where was the incentive? Value yourself, and that yes you can help them. We teach people how to treat us and this is no different.

post_text: I‚Äôm an OT and have a sole proprietorship. I have a contract for BCBS but the bulk of my patients are cash paying (more for personal training services.) I‚Äôm toying with hiring a contract PT to work VERY casually (2-8 patients/week.) If I get her a BCBS shield contract, how do I manage billing and paying her? She will get 70% of my cash rate charge. Do you also think it should be 70% or whatever she‚Äôs billing (will be substantially more.)

comments.text: I have done this in the past and I was paid a flat rate per patient. I was happy and so was the employer! Can you talk with the person to see what they think is fair?! Your cash rates might be higher than what BCBS reimburses, but I never like being incentivized for what I bill out. I like to bill what the patient needs. Just a thought!
I'd do a percentage of your average reimbursement/cash pay per visit looking at the past 6-12 months.

post_text:
Hi all! SLP here. I put in my notice to be done in June. I plan on working on the logistics for the summer and hitting the ground running with my own practice in the fall. 

One of the things I‚Äôm struggling with is the private pay structure - 100%, I‚Äôm not dealing with insurance but I also want to find a way to service the people who are not able to private pay. Isn‚Äôt private pay only sustainable to the few (client, wise?). TIA!

comments.text:
Private pay is sustainable but, as with most things in the therapy world, it depends. It depends on your clientele, skill set, niche, etc. 

Not all insurances are hard to deal with and not all insurances are bad. You can pick and choose how you work with what insurances and when. 

There are plenty of options to fit you, your practice and your patients. 

Good luck! And congrats!

Private pay is possible for those who value your service. I've had patients tell me that they rather use their insurance and could not afford to pay OOP and then contact me a few weeks later asking to schedule. If the service you provide is of value, then people will pay for the care they need and deserve.

post_text:
Advice! I‚Äôm ready to start seeing patients on a cash basis for a side hustle - ultimate goal will be to be solely on my own and out of corporate world. 

BUT I‚Äôm struggling to see how to get it to leap from side hustle to full time without that big income lag. We literally cannot afford for me to not have my income during any period of time (husband a teacher, two small kids, building a house‚Ä¶) How do you do this!?!

comments.text: I started mine on the side as well after I switched to PRN from full time OP. Due to the natural fluctuation of business, I still do PRN but the roles have reversed. PRN is now the side gig and my business is about 70% full. I have kept prn for security when I have slow months‚Ä¶this is my situation at 1.5 years in. Organic growth takes time, so if you can manage building it on the side for a while, that may be best until you have consistent and more predictable business income

Organic growth takes time, so if you can manage building it on the side for a while, that may be best until you have consistent and more predictable business income
