post_text:
The first photo came up in my memories today. It was my first ‚Äúoffice‚Äù 10 years ago.

It was a 6x10 walk in closet in a chiropractor‚Äôs office that I turned into a cozy therapy room.  My table was on furniture sliders it was so small.  Don‚Äôt ever let someone tell you a space is too small to launch your dream.  

The remaining photos are of my treatment room inside the wellness center I own today. 

The initial growth my business experienced came through inspiration but this past year it came through ‚Äúgrowing pains‚Äù instead. 

The memory of my first office popping up today reminded me of the sensation and feeling of inspiration I had for the first 10 years in business. It made me realize that over the past year I‚Äôve been functioning in a mode of fear/lack. Finally recognizing this, I was able to transition back into inspiration and wonderment.  Such a sign of relief!ü•∞

I hope you all find some inspiration or wonderment in your businesses today as well!! üíïüíï

The memory of my first office popping up today reminded me of the sensation and feeling of inspiration I had for the first 10 years in business. It made me realize that over the past year I‚Äôve been functioning in a mode of fear/lack. Finally recognizing this, I was able to transition back into inspiration and wonderment.  Such a sign of relief!ü•∞

I hope you all find some inspiration or wonderment in your businesses today as well!! üíïüíï

COMMENT 1: AWESOME!  Love the progression, Sarah Vose!!! CONGRATS!! Thank you for sharing!!!

COMMENT 2: Amazing! I literally just rented a space in a chiropractor‚Äôs office yesterday. Inspired by your growth and hopeful to get there one day.

post_text: Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

comments.text: My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value as well

full_thread_text:
POST: Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

COMMENT 1: My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

COMMENT 2: At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value as well

post_text:
Hello, I am considering buying out the outpatient practice I work in. I have a general idea of business valuation (~1.2x the average revenue over several years).  However, I've been told that since this is a service-based industry, it has less value when sold? 

For the clinicians who own a private outpatient practice, can you shed some insight on where to start or what resources to utilize to get a good understanding? I don't want to sound uncertain or confused once I start discussing this with my boss.  Thank you for your time!

comments.text: 100% get an attorney and have someone do due diligence on their finances before any offers are in the table
Don't do this without attorneys for contracts and accountant to make a proper valuation.  Can cost more upfront but can save you huge amounts of money down the road.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello, I am considering buying out the outpatient practice I work in. I have a general idea of business valuation (~1.2x the average revenue over several years).  However, I've been told that since this is a service-based industry, it has less value when sold? 

For the clinicians who own a private outpatient practice, can you shed some insight on where to start or what resources to utilize to get a good understanding? I don't want to sound uncertain or confused once I start discussing this with my boss.  Thank you for your time!

COMMENT 1: 100% get an attorney and have someone do due diligence on their finances before any offers are in the table

COMMENT 2: Don't do this without attorneys for contracts and accountant to make a proper valuation.  Can cost more upfront but can save you huge amounts of money down the road.

post_text: What is the best way to go about selling your business? There is a good chance that my husband is getting relocated and I'm trying to figure out what to do next. I'd really hate to just have to scrap everything I've worked for and pass my patients off to a different clinic.

comments.text: Tough, sole practitioner are tough to sell, cuz your patients like you. Start immediately, call every therapist you know and sell them on the idea of being there own boss and the financial benefits. Be honest and open. Make it a win -win. Someone wants to be in your shoes, GL

Is there any chance you can hire a PT and continue to operate the business from another state? You would do all the admin work and the therapist would see the patients. You would likely earn more from operating the business like this for a couple years instead of selling

post_text: I have a mobile practice that I co-own at 50% with a colleague. I have been approached by another old colleague who would like to join our business and said that she can likely bring clients that would follow her from an old job that is in the area. We do not have a huge amount of clients in the area (where my business partner, PTA resides) but are growing, so the most I could offer her as far as visits would be an IC situation currently. I would definitely love to have another PT to cover and work this this area though, so I could focus on continuing to grow the area closer to where I'm living. I guess where I am struggling, is what would make this deal "worth it" to her to partner with us vs. just starting her own mobile practice in the area? Thanks!

comments.text:
Multiple ‚Äúowners‚Äù makes this stuff such a headache.

Bring them on as a contractor. They get the benefit of autonomy. You take a % since you have all the systems set up. They can leave if they get unhappy and don‚Äôt have to worry about any sort of company equity. Everyone wins

Ask them... 
Have a dialogue with them and see what are their intentions goals values etc.

comments.text:
I love posts like these. It truly shifts perspectives. There is a buyer at every price point for every market. 

There are people who value this as a service at this price point while others don‚Äôt.

This isn‚Äôt a comparison of industries as much as its conviction to charge higher, belief in value provided, and selling to the right market that values it at that price point. 

We often can‚Äôt sell at higher rates because we‚Äôre judging someone else‚Äôs pockets as if it‚Äôs our own, or trying to sell to someone who doesn‚Äôt value the service already. 

I‚Äôm glad this was shared in here. Always shows what is possible if we‚Äôre willing to see it.
Literally talking about this today with a PT.

post_text:
"I lost 10 pounds in a week! Looking to lose weight before the holidays? Message me "fit for the holidays" and I'll give you information."

True store.  I really have lost 10 pounds over the last week stuck in bed with the flu.

Does this type of hook (attractive statement) sound familiar? We've all seen it. I've done something remarkable and want to share with others how they too can have the unprecedented success they've had. 

Does it seem too good to be true? 

Does it make sense to lose 10# in a week? Is that healthy? 

We want your business to grow and we want you to do it in as healthy a way as possible.

Fast growth can happen. We've had seasons of ridiculous growth in the past and some has been healthy but a lot of our fast growth hasn't been that healthy. 

It's not sexy to tell people to grow in a healthy way but that's what we're going to continue shouting from the rooftops.

comments.text:
Sustainable growth and laying a rock solid foundation are key! 

Keep teaching the right methods, your reputation and client outcomes will (and do) speak on your behalf. üëèüèº
Hope you are feeling better

post_text:
Need some advice/words of wisdom

I moved from a full time SNF + side hustle to 3 day part time at the SNF and 2 day part time working for my cash only practice at the beginning of November. I structure it typically for 60-75 min treatments and 90 minute evals and have been ramping up to 3-4 visits a week. So right now I am still pretty dependent on the income for those visits to replace the days not at the SNF (6 visits/wk is break even with expenses) I  heavily use counterstrain as a manual technique and that is generally what brings in the clients. The colleague/mentor who introduced me to this technique and had a part time cash practice recently told me they were moving out of state and said she would recommend her clients to see me when they needed therapy. Then, she also connected with a retired PT in the area who reached out who owned several insurance base clinics in the past and extensively studied counterstrain and was certified in it. At our first meeting, he mentioned that he isn‚Äôt getting satisfaction doing PRN 1-2 days a week for SNFs and doesn‚Äôt want all his knowledge with counterstrain to go to waste with him retiring. He told me his goal was to help my business grow and be able to pass on his knowledge. He mentioned money wasn‚Äôt important since he was retired and if I wanted to utilize him, then pay him what I felt he is worth. Of course with his business knowledge and clinical knowledge, my first thought was there was no way I can afford what he is worth. I know I‚Äôve had a lot of these doors just open in front of me and I want to take advantage of these opportunities but looking for some wisdom on how to utilize him to grow personally and grow the business to hopefully full time but also make a wise financial decision too. I‚Äôm meeting with him a second time soon but I‚Äôve been racking my brain on how to utilize him not just as a 2nd therapist to generate income but more as a mentor and how that would play out as well as how to pay him.

comments.text: I would have an honest conversation about what he wants you to pay him. Give him your honest situation and then ask him to tell you what he would do in his situation. Use that to make a decision on pay. I would highly recommend you co treat with him so you get better at counterstrain (it's mainly what I do). Mentorship with FCS is essential

Agree with David Harvitz you need to get a firm number in place before he starts providing services on your behalf. Sounds like a chill dude and doesn‚Äôt want to put stress on you, but trust me it will be more stressful trying to figure out what he is worth later as he either provides a lot of financial value, or doesn‚Äôt.

post_text: I would love to get ideas from this group on how you incentivize therapists and/or front desk (administrative assistant) to sweeten the pot and encourage retention. TIA!

comments.text:
from a general management perspective, understand what they value and give them more of that to show them your appreciation and that you understand what they value outside of work. 

Some people value money while others value time with their family. Some even value simply having a shoutout about them to the practice via a newsletter, or maybe even concert/ sporting event tickets. Not all incentives have to be monetary. 

This requires something that not many managers do and it‚Äôs to get to know your own staff much better and on a deeper level.
Find out why people are leaving. Treat them as you want to be treated. Respectful work environment, competitive pay, flexibility in schedule, etc.

post_text:
A question I'm pondering.
Do you build your business with legacy in mind?
IE: what happens to the business after I'm gone? Who will take over the reins? Can it go on without me?
OR
Do you build your business with an exit strategy?
IE: build it to a certain point then sell it?
OR
Do you just build it to serve you now and enjoy the ride?
If this one....what might the complications of closing the business look like that could be prepared for now?

comments.text:
1. Legacy is always in my mind. What footprint am I leaving for me, family and the population I serve.

2. I always have an exit strategy. I've sold my businesses back home in the Philippines. My daughters are taking over my business once they are done with PTA or otr np school. üòÅüòÅüòÅ

This is such a personal decision based on so many factors! I am three years in and I don‚Äôt have a definite plan, although I do make decisions with the thought in mind to potentially eventually sell the business, but you never know. If the business is providing for me financially, and it‚Äôs not causing a lot of stress than there may be no reason to sell it. if one of my adult children wants to take it over at some point then that might be the answer. At this point, just trying to build and grow and not make the decision right away. Ôøº

post_text: Not PT related, and not looking for medical advice. Just a general question: is shin pain common with growing pains? My oldest son will be 10 in Aug, and is on the small side so I‚Äôm expecting a growth spurt soon. He‚Äôs very active and pretty much never complains about pain, but was in tears this morning telling me he‚Äôs had shin pain for ‚Äúweeks‚Äù. Apparently it‚Äôs inconsistent, not worse at night or with activity. I never had growing pains, so I have no idea, and I always have an underlying and probably unreasonable fear of osteosarcoma.

comments.text: Could be shin splints.  I had that as a teen.  Horrible pain.  There is taping to help try YouTube and see if that helps

My son had horrible growing pains. His dad also had Osgood -Schlatters in his middle school years and had horrible pains. Might look into a cho-pat brace to wear with activities, it might offer some relief. Always good to have him checked out.

full_thread_text:
POST: Not PT related, and not looking for medical advice. Just a general question: is shin pain common with growing pains? My oldest son will be 10 in Aug, and is on the small side so I‚Äôm expecting a growth spurt soon. He‚Äôs very active and pretty much never complains about pain, but was in tears this morning telling me he‚Äôs had shin pain for ‚Äúweeks‚Äù. Apparently it‚Äôs inconsistent, not worse at night or with activity. I never had growing pains, so I have no idea, and I always have an underlying and probably unreasonable fear of osteosarcoma.

COMMENT 1: Could be shin splints.  I had that as a teen.  Horrible pain.  There is taping to help try YouTube and see if that helps

COMMENT 2: My son had horrible growing pains. His dad also had Osgood -Schlatters in his middle school years and had horrible pains. Might look into a cho-pat brace to wear with activities, it might offer some relief. Always good to have him checked out.

post_text: I figured this group could be a great resource. What is the market pulse in private practice business Valuation in 2023? I think the industry standard is adjusted EBITDA multiple of 3-5X. Are most calculating EBITDA off trailing 12 months, past year, or average of past years. Anyone will to chat or who might have any insight in this area would be much appreciated.

comments.text:
Unfortunately there is no exact science for business valuation and depends on so many factors such as years in business, location, local and outside competition etc. 
Normally it is last 3 years weighted SDE or EBITDA. I have seen therapy practices sell for 2 to 3 multiples. Occasionally 4, IF the seller sees exponential growth in the future. Hope this helps.
that multiplle is high for my area.  closer to 1x AR.

full_thread_text:
POST: I figured this group could be a great resource. What is the market pulse in private practice business Valuation in 2023? I think the industry standard is adjusted EBITDA multiple of 3-5X. Are most calculating EBITDA off trailing 12 months, past year, or average of past years. Anyone will to chat or who might have any insight in this area would be much appreciated.

COMMENT 1: Unfortunately there is no exact science for business valuation and depends on so many factors such as years in business, location, local and outside competition etc. 
Normally it is last 3 years weighted SDE or EBITDA. I have seen therapy practices sell for 2 to 3 multiples. Occasionally 4, IF the seller sees exponential growth in the future. Hope this helps.

post_text:
I‚Äôm growing impatient. I‚Äôm a mobile massage therapist for now, doing fine. I have much more to offer, and I feel I would grow faster if I have a physical space. 

PhD in Human and Sports Performance
MA in Sport Psychology
LMT
CSCS

What are some resources that could help me break the mental blocks and go for that physical space? Right now I feel like I‚Äôm in a catch-22 situation where I need more clients and revenue to justify the rental space, but if I had a rental space I could have greater biz growth and potential. How can I get from where I am to where I want to be? Thanks

comments.text:
You already said it. You will grow faster with a physical space. I say go for it! That's what I did. üòÅüòÅüòÅ

Just took the leap of faith and the rest is history. üòÅüòÅüòÅ

Look all the time for rental spaces. You need to find the happy medium between great location and affordable. When I signed my lease in Jan this year I had literally 2 clients and neither of them were people who could come in to my studio. I was taking a huge risk, but the space I found was never going to come back again. So I took the leap, and now a slow week for me is 18 visits working 8:30-2:30, including seeing those 2 clients at their homes still. All this is to say: the number are scary. Risk is scary. But we have to do scary things to accomplish stuff‚Ä¶ so take the leap! You can do it!

post_text:
üó£Ô∏èA MESSAGE‚ÄºÔ∏è

A violinist played for 45 minutes in the New York subway.  A handful of people stopped, a couple clapped, and the violinist raised about $30 in tips. 

No one knew this, but the violinist was Joshua Bell, one of the best musicians in the world. In that subway, Joshua played one of the most intricate pieces ever written with a violin worth 3.5 million dollars.

Two days before he played in the subway, Joshua Bell sold out a Boston theatre, and the seats averaged about $100. 

The experiment proved that the extraordinary in an ordinary environment does not shine and is so often overlooked and undervalued.

There are brilliantly talented people everywhere who aren‚Äôt receiving the recognition and reward they deserve. But once they arm themselves with value and confidence and remove themselves from an environment that isn‚Äôt serving them, they thrive and grow. 

Your gut is telling you something. Listen to it if it‚Äôs telling you where you are isn‚Äôt enough! 

Go where you are appreciated and valued. 

Know Your Worth.

@shaynevibes_truth

comments.text: Love this
Great message üôå

post_text: Is it worth it to purchase the domain you want in .com (for $2500) if .org is currently available?

comments.text: Buy them all. If you‚Äôve done a good job with a business name, owning all digital real estate is important.

Agree with others. If you can tweak it a little to get the .com I‚Äôd go that route but if not choosing another works too. The typical understanding of .org for organizations and things like that is shifting since we are running out of urls. But also depends a little on your clientele in my opinion. If you are targeting an older population, stick with .com for sure. Younger population more understanding of difference url endings.

full_thread_text:
POST: Is it worth it to purchase the domain you want in .com (for $2500) if .org is currently available?

COMMENT 1: Buy them all. If you‚Äôve done a good job with a business name, owning all digital real estate is important.

COMMENT 2: Agree with others. If you can tweak it a little to get the .com I‚Äôd go that route but if not choosing another works too. The typical understanding of .org for organizations and things like that is shifting since we are running out of urls. But also depends a little on your clientele in my opinion. If you are targeting an older population, stick with .com for sure. Younger population more understanding of difference url endings.
